Article.ArticleTitle: Examining the Shape of the Association between Low Levels of Fine Particulate Matter and Mortality across Three Cycles of the Canadian Census Health and Environment Cohort.

AbstractText: Ambient fine particulate air pollution with aerodynamic diameter <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>m</mi></mrow></math> (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) is an important contributor to the global burden of disease. Information on the shape of the concentration-response relationship at low concentrations is critical for estimating this burden, setting air quality standards, and in benefits assessments.

We examined the concentration-response relationship between <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and nonaccidental mortality in three Canadian Census Health and Environment Cohorts (CanCHECs) based on the 1991, 1996, and 2001 census cycles linked to mobility and mortality data.

Census respondents were linked with death records through 2016, resulting in 8.5 million adults, 150 million years of follow-up, and 1.5 million deaths. Using annual mailing address, we assigned time-varying contextual variables and 3-y moving-average ambient <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> at a <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>km</mi></mrow></math> spatial resolution from 1988 to 2015. We ran Cox proportional hazards models for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> adjusted for eight subject-level indicators of socioeconomic status, seven contextual covariates, ozone, nitrogen dioxide, and combined oxidative potential. We used three statistical methods to examine the shape of the concentration-response relationship between <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and nonaccidental mortality.

The mean 3-y annual average estimate of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> exposure ranged from 6.7 to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>8.0</mn><msup><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow></math> over the three cohorts. We estimated a hazard ratio (HR) of 1.053 [95% confidence interval (CI): 1.041, 1.065] per <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>10</mn><msup><mrow><mtext>-</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow></math> change in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> after pooling the three cohort-specific hazard ratios, with some variation between cohorts (1.041 for the 1991 and 1996 cohorts and 1.084 for the 2001 cohort). We observed a supralinear association in all three cohorts. The lower bound of the 95% CIs exceeded unity for all concentrations in the 1991 cohort, for concentrations above <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow></math> in the 1996 cohort, and above <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>5</mn><msup><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow></math> in the 2001 cohort.

In a very large population-based cohort with up to 25 y of follow-up, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>PM</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> was associated with nonaccidental mortality at concentrations as low as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>5</mn><msup><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow></math>. https://doi.org/10.1289/EHP5204.
